717079f-a.text:
Broadway, south from John Street. In the right background is the spire of Trinity Church, at the head of Wall Street.
About 1880
American Studio, phpto
87 Nassau St., N.W.C.
Gift of Urbrock Collection

717083f-b.text:
195 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Dey Street (left) showing the 11-story Western Union Building under demolition. Upon this site, in conjunction with three additional plots numbered 14, 16 and 18 Dey Street, will rise the new 28-story Western Union Building. On Dey Street appears an extensive view westward from Broadway to the North (Hudson) River. The tower appearing on the right is atop the Mail and Exptess Building. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
1913.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

717083f-a.text:
195 Broadway, at the N.W. corner of Dey Street (left) showing the 11-story Western Union Building under demolition. Upon this site, in conjunction with three additional plots numbered 14, 16 and 18 Dey Street, will rise the new 28-story Western Union Building. On Dey Street appears an extensive view westward from Broadway to the North (Hudson) River. The tower appearing on the right is atop the Mail and Exptess Building. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
1913.
F. M. Demarest.
Gift of Albert A. Volk Co.

717080f-a.text:
191-189 & 187 Broadway, at and adjoining the S.W. corner of Dey Street. Shown on the right is a vacant lot, which on the 1922 Bromley Map of New York City is occupied by the 15 story Gillespie Building, No. 5 Dey St.
Gift of E. M. Jenks  Prior to 1916

717088f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, north from but not including John Street to Park Row. On the extreme left, appears the United States Post Office, with the 25-story St. Paul building and the 7-story, ornate Chase National Building (National Park Branch) preceding.
December 27, 1936.
P.L. Sperr.
(2)
A portion of the view shown in No. 1, in a southward direction. On the extreme left, appears a portion of the Chase National Bank, with the 6-story United Building adjoining (N.E. corner of Fulton Street).
December 27, 1936.
P.L. Sperr.
(3)
A view of the stores in the 10-story building, No. 204-210 Broadway, at the S.E. corner of Fulton Street. This property has been leased for 21 years. The present structure is to be demolished and a 2-story
building constructed on its site.
December 27, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
No. 204-21O Broadway (also No. 156 Fulton Street), the building to be razed is the former home of the Evening Post. This structure shown was one of the first large office buildings to be erected in New York. For a further account and a picture of same, see Kings
Hand book of New York 1892 page 567.
